results.title: Peer Pressure Trigger Tapes
results.brief_description: Three exciting short films about peer pressure. 1)”Sticks and Toby” Two best friends, a thin boy and a fat boy, go swimming. Toby, the fat boy, is teased by a group of boys who want Sticks to join them. What should Sticks do? “The Gang”: Ting Lee wants to join a gang at her school. In her new hairstyle and jacket they finally accept her. But then they pressure her to smoke! “Tough Rules” Max and his friends do lots of fun things together. One day, they decide they should each steal something. Max doesn’t like stealing, but doesn’t want to lose his friends.

results.title: Ironbark Bill
results.creator_credit: Philip Pepper, Don Ezard and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: This animated tale tells a raunchy, rocky, hilarious story of the legendary Ironbark Bill and the champion Buckjumper, a high-spirited horse who bounces so high in his bucking that rider and horse end up in the clouds. The problem, then, is how to get down. It is based on Australian writer, Dal Stivens “Ironbark Bill” tall tales.

results.title: Mother and son. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Portmann, ABC-TV (Australia) and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description: Ruth Cracknell and Gary McDonald are brilliant as Maggie and Arthur. Henri Szeps is Robert, the brother you love to hate, with Judy Morris as his wife, Liz. Maggie appears to be losing her memory, but still knows how to enjoy life. Arthur yearns to be free from the responsibility of caring for Maggie, but he’s stuck, and Maggie makes the most of it. This tape includes three episodes: “The Money” - Maggie has been saving up her pension cheques and hiding them away. “The Aunt” - Arthur invites Maggie’s sister, Lorna, over for a visit. “The Accident” - Arthur injures his foot and Maggie has to look after him.

results.title: Time bandits
results.creator_credit: Terry Gilliam and Handmade Films Partnership
results.brief_description: Time Bandits is a Pythonesque fantasy jaunt through time and space. The 11 year old hero finds his bedroom invaded by amiable, rascally dwarfs, absconding employees of the Supreme Being. They take him on an exhilarating journey through time and space. As might be expected, the giants of history and legend turn out to be engaging eccentrics.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Insight into the techniques and working conditions of the women employed to manufacture “Clarice Cliff” pottery under her direction. The influence of these women on Cliff’s career. Interviews with Gordon Elliot (historian), Susie Cooper (designer), Peggy Davies (sculptor) and Ethel Cliff.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Colin Melbourne (former head of Burslem Art School), Peggy Davies (pottery sculptor) and Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian) discuss the relationship between the Burslem Art School and the pottery industry and the influences on the works of the designers Susie Cooper, Charlotte Rhead and Clarice Cliff.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Joan Jackson (Rhead’s biographer), Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian), Barry Leigh (manufacturer) and the women employed in the manufacturing process of Rhead’s work discuss and trace the history, influences and production techniques of Charlotte Rhead’s work.

results.title: The Greenhouse effect (BBC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas adds more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. This colourless, odourless, naturally occurring gas turns the atmosphere into a giant greenhouse, trapping more of the sun’s heat and raising the temperature each year. This informative documentary looks at the causes behind the greenhouse effect and the resulting possible changes in the earth’s environment.

results.title: 26 Bathrooms
results.brief_description: Peter Greenaway uses visual imagery to present this warm and humorous look at people and their bathrooms, revealing that the bathroom is used for far more than the daily duties of cleanliness and hygiene. We see people soaking, dozing, eating, reading, chatting and watching television in surroundings that range from plain porcelain to the “Samuel Beckett Memorial Bathroom”.
results.description: Peter Greenaway uses visual imagery to present this warm and humorous look at people and their bathrooms, revealing that the bathroom is used for far more than the daily duties of cleanliness and hygiene. We see people soaking, dozing, eating, reading, chatting and watching television in surroundings that range from plain porcelain to the “Samuel Beckett Memorial Bathroom”.

results.title: Cane toads: an unnatural history
results.creator_credit: Mark Lewis, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Bufo Marinus, the cane toad, was introduced into Queensland in 1935 for a specific reason - to combat the grey-back beetle that was destroying the sugar cane crop. The mission failed : the beetle could fly and the cane toad couldn’t. Oblivious of its failure, the cane toad settled extremely well into its new surroundings and proceeded to breed so rapidly that it has now become a pest of plague proportions. This amusing documentary blends biological fact with human comment to show how the cane toads have become an accepted part of local culture and popular mythology.
